content: back-to-basics this week it's a simple piece of scatter terrain with some tips
on how to make a good solid base for your larger terrain pieces take some
dollar-store foam board and draw out sort of a rounded triangle shape as you
see here trace the shape on to chip board cut out around it apply glue stick
to both surfaces and give it about 30 seconds to become tacky I found that
this helps ensure an instant strong bond then use scissors to trim off the excess
chipboard so it's perfectly flush with the foam board extend your crafting
knife out pretty far and chamfer the edge at a shallow angle in other words
you don't want the knife perpendicular and you don't want it totally parallel
you want it slightly above parallel like this make sure the blade is fresh and
that you are drawing across the material as if using a saw and you'll find that
it shaves off very nicely then get some sandpaper this is 150 grit
but 220 would be fine also and just smooth out those tapers and now we have
a really nice-looking base professional wargame terrain makers like to use a
thin MDF board which they then chamfer with a knife or a sander but this method
requires no power tools and no MDF board by the way glue stick doesn't warp
nearly as bad as white PVA glue and that's why I use it now take two pieces
of some dollar-store foam board about eight inches square peel the paper off
one side of each and glue stick them together now measure your base to see
how much area you have in this case I had about four inches in each direction
so that's what I went with and I drew on the shape of a wall
segment on my double thick foam piece and cut it out I figured that four
inches high would be a good height for terrain for my kings of wargames then I
cut the other wall making sure that would match up with the first one
apply a texture to the walls however you like we've discussed techniques many
times before and then hot glue them to the base and
to each other I picked out a couple spots on the base
and applied a brick texture to them then brush on white PVA glue ignoring the
brick spots and flock with pebbles and sand
face the whole piece in black sponge on dark ray to the walls and the ground
spots while that's drying we apply a solid base coat of burnt umber for all
of the flocked area and then while that's drying we can sponge on a light
gray to all the stone once everything is bone-dry
I used craft smart suede and dry brush to the sand with it
now apply our white glue water mixture to the sanded area I know in the past
I've mentioned like 2/3 PVA one-third water but honestly anything close to
50/50 will work it's hard to mess up just make sure the mixture flows
slightly thicker than plain water this is important because the flock can
absorb the mixture and you get a nice blanket a flock instead of a thin layer
after it dries completely brush off the excess and if you want to apply another
coat of mixture to seal it all in finally this is a bag of assorted moss
that I got from the crafting store I'm just gonna hot glue a couple pieces in
place I am wild Locke thank you for joining me
and I'll see you next time you
